summary: This is a government contract (Standard Form 1449) between the Federal Bureau of Prisons and Signet Technologies, Inc. for the purchase and installation of a camera system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The contract is valued at $698,108.99 and includes detailed specifications for video surveillance equipment and related services. This document is a detailed security and confidentiality clause from a Department of Justice (DOJ) contract. It outlines stringent requirements for a contractor handling DOJ Information, including definitions, IT security compliance, cloud computing rules, and procedures for reporting security breaches. It is a standard government contract clause focused on data protection. This document contains standard government contract clauses related to subcontractor compliance, contractor performance evaluation using CPARS, Section 508 accessibility requirements, and corporate felony conviction/tax liability representations. It appears to be part of a Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) contract document.

keyFacts: The Federal Bureau of Prisons contracted with Signet Technologies, Inc. for a $698,108.99 camera system installation at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.
The contract includes detailed specifications for a 'Nice Vision Enterprise' video surveillance system, including recorders, encoders, decoders, and numerous IP cameras.
The document is a standard government procurement form (SF 1449) and includes extensive contractual clauses related to security, hazardous materials, and personnel requirements.
The contract specifies that the Facilities Manager at MCC New York is designated as the Contracting Officer's Representative (COR), though the individual's name is not provided in this excerpt.
The contract includes Homeland Security Presidential Directive-12 (HSPD-12) compliance requirements for contractor personnel security and background investigations.
The document defines 'DOJ Information' as any information owned, produced, or controlled by the Department of Justice, including personal identifiable information (PII).
It imposes strict IT security requirements on contractors, mandating compliance with FISMA, NIST standards, and DOJ IT Security Standards (DOJ Order 2640.2).
Contractors are prohibited from allowing non-U.S. citizens to access DOJ Information Systems without a specific waiver from DOJ officials.
The clause requires immediate reporting (within 1 hour) of any Confirmed Security Breach to the DOJ Contracting Officer (CO) or the DOJ Computer Emergency Readiness Team (DOJ-CERT).
All DOJ Information and deliverables produced under the contract are the property of the U.S. Government, and contractors cannot release them to third parties without prior written permission.
The document contains Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) contract clauses requiring compliance from all subcontractors and cloud service providers.
Contractor performance is evaluated using the Department of Defense's Contractor Performance Assessment Reporting System (CPARS).
The contract includes Section 508 compliance requirements for electronic and information technology accessibility.
The contract prohibits awards to corporations convicted of felonies under federal law within the preceding 24 months or with unpaid federal tax liabilities.
The document references standard government contracting procedures including FAR (Federal Acquisition Regulation) compliance.
